20598748.review:
[h1]├ Digitals Review 👌🏻 ┤[/h1]
[h1]Overall Score[/h1]
[b]65/100[/b]

[b]Game Pros[/b]
• Very clean menu
• Spawn protection 
• Forever growing crafting/cooking system
• Wierdly satisfying graphics
• Base Building
• Melee Weapons & Guns 
• Very smooth and easy to run (Never get frame drops unless it's server side. Constant 45-60fps+) 
• Various biomes all containing different animals/materials (Some biomes have more of one thing than others)
• Weather system (Rain/Sun/Dust Storms etc..) All of which effects characters stability 
• Driveable cars (Find the car chasis on the map and apply wheels/motor accesories) Remember to make some gas! 
• Consistent updates
• Moddable custom servers
• Online livemap to see your character and any friends (Those familiar with Rust already know what this is) 

[b]Game Cons[/b]
• High pop servers tend to have minor rubberbanding/lag. Not enough to actually leave the server, but it's there
• The voice that plays to indicate you're hungry, or full, can get annoying. Sounds like it was recorded on a cheap mic. I don't get it.
• (Please leave any further cons in the comments. More will be added [i](hopefully not)[/i] as players call them out)

[b]Controversial[/b]
• You keep your clothing and hotbar items upon death (Might be different on some servers, I honestly havent checked)

[b]Relateable Games[/b]
• Rust Legacy

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
If you enjoyed Rust Legacy, or are just looking for a new survival game to get into, Hurtworld is where it's at. At first I didn't thing i'd enjoy it as much I did. But once you really get into it, things get intense pretty quick. I would reccomend this game to anyone who likes the survival type genre. 37992821.review:
I started playing HurtWorld December of 2015 and had a blast playing with my friends. Early on there was a lot of bugs. Too many vehicles in the same proximity used to make servers lag and the "fix" for that was to make it so each player has to "claim" a vehicle. This didn't fix the lag issue as players still accumulated tons of vehicles. A few years have passed and the game has taken a turn for the worse. Rock/wall glitching was a huge issue for a while as I had many of my bases raided by foreigners exploiting those methods. Raiding would sometimes be pointless as a player would log out with their good items on their character(s) would disappear with their character as they logged out. To kill two birds with one stone the devs decided that the "fix" was to create a "player box"(sleeping character) when you log out instead of your body vanishing with all of the items like before. You're unable to climb through windows in the game which doesn't make much sense, originally when implamented you were able to crawl through windows. Instead of making a few changes to the original game the devs decided to scrap the original game and create a new version of the game (V2) which is a Rust mock and ruins the foundations of the game that worked. Content was promised and never delivered. Still waiting for the SMG, saber tooth tiger, and flying bugs.
(*Personal opinion* Things that could have saved Hurtworld) The devs should have tweaked and created more content for version 1. Simple things like random creature spawn locations, clothing coloring (to differentiate players since everyone looks like Ronald McDonald), adding new weapons and food resources.
I really miss what this game USED to be. Fingers are crossed that the devs get their heads on straight and listen to the community instead of assuming what the players want. We don't want Rust, if we wanted Rust then we would play Rust.
Make HurtWorld great again!
In its current state I would not recommend purchasing this game. Wait for some positive changes to happen with the development of the game before getting disappointed.

19571225.review:
I've played tons of survival games and have hundreds of hours across most of them so I think I have some legitimate grounds on my opinion on the release of this game and what they've created thus far.

The release was smooth as butter. No huge traffic or server crashes. Every once and a while a server goes down but it quickly comes back up. This is your basic survival game. If you were a fan of Rust Legacy than you will more than enjoy this game. Start at nothing, then end up with everything. They made C4 EXTREMELY hard to get so you have to truly hate someone in order to raid their base.

The best part about the game is the Infamy System. Let me explain what that is. You have your basic tools, gear (cloths) and items including resources and ammo and such.  When you're starting out and get killed by another player you will lose all of your ammo and resources BUT NOT lose your tools and clothing, basically the essentials. If you've killed another player you get infamy which means for 15 minutes if you die, you have a chance of dropping your tools such as guns, pickaxes and other things. This will stack higher and higher if the player does not let his infamy disappear first.

This makes the game so much better due to the fact that not EVERYONE will KOS. You will need to be cautious.

Game is 10/10

19923854.review:
I have a problem: I am compelled to buy half-complete early access titles in the Survival-Crafting Open World PVP genre. It's like a curse, in which my wallet and my happiness must suffer. So naturally, I wanted to give Hurtworld a try. I was [i]compelled[/i] to. 

I logged into a server and immediately encountered a neutral player trying to shoo me from his gathering area. He threw his spear at me, missing, all the while communicating to me with voice chat to go away. Point taken, I high tailed it out of there half-naked and with nothing to my name. A couple nights later I had established some basic tools but died of hypothermia. I have not died since. You learn to prioritize resource gathering and craftables, to keep a campfire at the ready for the harsh cold nights. I encountered friendly players, who offered some spare leather or had a kind word in passing. But I also encountered my first hostile player, who tried to coerce me into dropping all my logs. I refused and he chased me with his bow. I turned on him, spear in hand, and wacked him over the head. He didn't like that. I chased him off with my stick and very suddenly a blinding dust storm kicked up. He complained about not being able to see and I used that opportunity to get away -- even though I was the one chasing him. It felt great, as a new player, to be able to defend myself against others. And even better to see how the environment had protected me and given me cover. Cool. 

A few hours of gameplay later and I have claimed a plot of land, clothed myself, crafted a back pack, built a small home, stocked up my storage container, created tier 2 tools, and am ready to explore. I feel I have met small milestones and there is a sense of accomplishment and survival. I have hunted and gathered my way to basic comfort and survived the few hostile players. 

What the future holds, I am uncertain. I'd like to believe I cannot progress through the game so quickly. I'd like to believe great dangers lurk where great rewards lie, but I have not explored far enough yet.

Here's what I do know: The game is fun, it is a solid title for Early Access, the community isn't totally filled with jerks (at least not on the server I joined), and I can only hope the developers expand on this game as I want more of it. 

[b]-Pros-[/b]
+While it is an EA title, it feels like a solid game with a full feature list. Highly playable.
+Runs smoothly, no crashes, high frame rates
+Combat is adequate
+Survival takes some effort and thought during the first couple hours
+Basic resources continue to be useful
+Player community
+I not YET encountered a cheater
+The server I play on is not full when I want to play
+Its fun
+You keep your tools when you die, but drop your resources
+HUD is clutter free


[b]-Cons/Other Thoughts-[/b]
-Hypothermia is a bit harsh

-Overheating mechanic is ridiculous. I'd understand if you overheat from the desert sun. But instead you overheat from being near your campfire or firepit, which is required for cooking food and smelting ores. It is ridiculous that I can't be anywhere inside my house while the firepit is going or I will start to overheat. Overheating can very well kill you. This could turn into an interesting mechanic if water is required to cool down from the hot desert or player must find shade or equip special gear. Tedius, but could be interesting. As it is right now its downright annoying. 

-Some resources will appear at a certain distance away, but will not be there when you approach, and may reapper after wandering around a bit. Similarly, the LOD on creatures is questionable. Bors can look a bit like logs at a distance because they are boxy until you get close enough for their details to be clear. And sometimes they won't appear at all until right up next them. Minor bugs. 

-Building a home is nice, but needs some work. There are no stairs or ladders. And you do not get any of your resources returned when you destroy something you've built. Certain resource requirements make no sense.

-Crafting menus could be improved on, but not really a con. They work as intended.


Overall, for 20$ I am enjoying the game and look forward to playing more of it.

20012694.review:
[h1] Alpha Review - 55h	[/h1]

Purchased it five days ago, and have played non-stop since. I know this is a fact everyone knows, but it is a Rust clone, and to be honest, I'm fine with that. The game does some things better than Rust, some things worse. It's cartoonish appearance makes it interesting. Vivid colors and clear contrast is half it's charm. The hardcore factor is not really true though. There is nothing in this game that is hardcore. Within an hour of playing, you will know the game mechanics and how most necessities work.

[h1] PROS 	[/h1]

-Beautiful graphics
As I said earlier, the graphics are amazing. They need more polishing, but they are pretty nonetheless. Gun textures are pretty dull though. I would choose this game over Rust when it comes to graphics.

-A sense of achievement
This is something the game nailed. When it's so easy to lose your resources, building a huge fortress feels amazing. The fact that the whole world is working against you makes every little upgrade worthwhile, and pretty satisfying. The simple upgrade from an Iron Hatchet to a Gold one is pure bliss.

-Nice building model
The building in this game is actually pretty stellar. You shape your house as you please, and that's something we didn't have in Rust. (More in Cons)

-Cars
Amazing for transportation, really cool models aswell. (More on this in the cons)

-Great open map
They really did a good job on the map. The hill areas need polishing, but the overall map is epic. Making a base in each biome is a must-do task. 

[h1] CONS 	[/h1]

-The Servers
Oh my God. I realize that we are currently in the Alpha Stage, but the servers are garbage. With the rumor of new servers, I hope that I can one day edit this part out. You'll often find yourself shooting at a boar, just to find out it has teleporting abilities with will literally be a pain in the ass. 

-Cars
I know I put ''Cars'' in the Pros aswell, and this is why; The chances of you ever getting a car in this game are so slim you would have more luck getting a car in Minecraft. The drop rates for car parts are garbage, and after 55hours of play with a whole clan of people, we have managed to get three wheels. Not to mention the sheer amount of bugs with vehicles. Sounds glitching, clipping through the map, randomly getting thrown out... If you are buying this game for the cars, don't bother.

-''Infamous'' System
I realize that this is here to make the game a bit more unique, but in my opinion it is one of this game's worst features. A rich individual can go to spawn and go bananas on some fresh-spawns without much consequence. This game's whole thing is it's hardcore factor, and this is where the hardcore factor goes away. Tools are harder to make, but you will always keep them as long as you don't kill anyone.

-Community
This doesn't really go under the CONS area, because the Devs can't change this; but it is worth mentioning nonetheless. If you have never played games like DayZ, Rust, and like like, be prepared to be KOS'd. There doesn't need to be a reason behind your death, as long as the Russian behind the scope is trigger happy. The Infamous system counteracts this to a certain degree. 

-Bugs and Glitches
I know this is completely normal in an Early-Access game, but nonetheless worth mentioning. The game is plagued with game-breaking glitches and annoyances. The whole Survive-bar is annoying as all hell. The Wetness factor and Temperature need so much fixing it shouldn't be in the game yet. 

[h1] SUGGESTIONS	[/h1]

-Party System / Friends
Even though you can share your house with your teammates, there is no way to identify them. No way of adding them on a friendlist, or mark them some way. Forget playing together if you don't use TS3 or the like. (You should do this anyway) This should be implied as soon as possible. 

-Drop Rates
Some fixing needs to be done with this. At the moment, they are completely horrendeous and need fixing. 

-Map
This game is in desperate need of some type of map. We currently have a ''compass'' which shows the user it's homes/bases, but no real way of knowing the area. Combining the Beacon and a map function would make this game a lot easier and more enjoyable to play.


All in all, this is a game worth trying. If you are a fan of Rust or DayZ, it's a truly refreshing. Even though there are a lot of Cons, I still love this game for what it is, and I hope they will fix some of these.
[h1] Rating: 8/10	[/h1]

Edit; 2. Jan 2015: Suggestions, Maps

22789514.review:
There are couple of problems I encoutered with this game and to me, they are egregious enough to me that I feel the need to warn other potential consumers.

Harvesting:

You start with literally nothing. Your avatar may have some boxer shorts on, but they are part of the character model and you truly have nothing. So you start your journey picking up whatever tidbits are on the floor in order to build some basic tools, which would be fine if the harvesting wasn't partially RNG based. Often times, completely identical looking stones on the ground will give you different resources, so you can never be sure that you are ever getting closer towards your goal.

Once you have some Tools, perhaps the Axe, a persons first thought would be to hack at trees right? Trees must give wood, that's logical. 

Wrong.

You can only harvest fallen logs in the world and dried up dead trees that exist in certain places in the world. Healthy trees cause your Axe to bounce off harmlessly.

The other resource node you can harvest look like sculptures of colored rocks, which require that you have a pick on you. Different colored nodes yield different quantities of resources, but you will never be certain of exactly what you will harvest due to the inane RNG harvesting thing I mentioned before.

This is further made frustrating in the way harvesting takes place. You left click on the resource node with the appropriate tool until the node breaks apart and only at the end of the break do you gain resources. If someone comes running by and has a higher level harvesting tool, they end up dealing more damage to the node and will manage to harvest your node before you could ever do.

Combine this with absurd costs of various items and the rarity of certain resources, this creates a scenario where a player is likely never to know exactly what they need in order to get the goals they desire.

Which leads me to the second bit I despise.

Player Killing:

This game handles player vs player interactions with a sort of karma system. When a player with no bad karma kills another player with no bad karma, they get a visible timer on them that shows how long they are marked. I forget the in game name of this mechanic, but suffice to say, this is something that is often abused.

Let me explain.

A player with no karma timer on them, when killed, retains all their gear and clothes upon death and spawns with it in their inventory. A player who dies while their karma timer is still active loses all their items.

This sounds like a nice way for non-violent players to play the game, but any player who dies still loses all their resources. Often times, groups of players will harass other players into killing them just so that their buddies can come and kill the now karma marked player and loot all his items. 

This system manages to not solve the horrid KOS problem prevalent with these survival games at all and even makes the experience worse for those players who successfullly defend themselves only to then be killed and lose EVERYTHING as opposed to just their resources.

It's dispicable.

The last problem I had with this had to the frequent server restarts.

Every 20 minutes, it seemed, servers have to restart, which requires that every player on the server get disconnected, wait a few moments and then manually reconnect.

Players only get a 5 minute warning of when this will happen, which is never enough time for players to find a safe area to be in before the restart.

When a player finally logs back in, they may find that other players are there already and have killed the player while they were spawning into the world.

It's awfully annoying for a server to have to restart so frequently to start with, but then logging back into the game just to find yourself dead is just unacceptable to me.

I do not recommend this game. 24 dollars is just not a sensible price when there are games in the survival genre that are much MUCH more developed and thought out than this game and also cost less.

YOU GUYS COULD BE PLAYING SOMETHING THAT IS SLIGHTLY MORE FUN THAN THIS FOR SLIGHTLY LESS THAN THIS GAME COSTS!!

Anyway, I didn't realy have fun with this game at all, I didn't find it's crafting intuitive in the least nor did I enjoy the combat or survival systems. The community was meh, but that's to be expected in these games.

All in all, I'd say look elsewhere for your survival gaming. This game is just not fun.

EDIT 5/4/2016..

As someone was so kind to point out, this is an Early Access title and potential purchasers should expect problems with the product. So while I understand that an Early Access title is not finished, I am reviewing this game based on what is currently available and what I have played, not on what the game might be when it's finished.

As always, do your research on EA titles and wary. My "NO" on recomending this game still stands.

28874484.review:
I've been playing Hurtworld for close to 200 hours now and I would like to give you guys an idea of what you get into.

Hurtworld is a survival game - and by definition, survival is (and should be) hard! There are a lot of people who are complaining about players who kill beginners at the starting-area. While I believe this is by far not as common as it was ... it is not a big of a deal if you do what the game is all about: sneak around, know that (in the beginning) you are weak and an easy target, be smart and make smart decision; in short: Survive!

Once you get the basics going, the game is a grind. You will be constantly grinding for ressources in order to get better gear, tools and build bases in various different areas. You can be in PVP-situations every time you play, but most times you have a choice not to seek a fight by sneaking around. 
Once you have the ressources to build a base, the desire will hit you to create a big one. The building-system is awesome and for the first time since World of Warcraft, I did not get bored grinding because building is so much fun. 

However, just as you can get killed in a classic pvp-weapon-fight: Your base can be raided and destroyed as well. And it will. 
The game is basically (!) a great experience if you'd like to team up with friends, it has lovely graphics and just all around a great feeling.

The reason why I would like to disadvise and warn you to buy this game is simple: Hacking. It's a HUGE problem in Hurtworld, it has ever been and the dev's don't take it too seriously. 
If you build a game in which the core value is grinding and securing your stuff in your base - the least you want is Hackers who compromise the game by using scripts that enable them to see what you have grinded. There are numerous hacks out there and they are frequently used. Search for "Hurtworld hack" on youtube and you will find ones from even October 2016. 

Hurtworld integrated EasyAntiCheat recently but EAC does not detect all scripts. In fact, cheating in Hurtworld is common. 

As much as I like the mechanics and the potential of this game ... you have to know that from mid-stage in the game on, you will not be grinding for yourself, but for the hackers who will raid your base(s) soon.

As a developer, you can build the best survival-building-pvp-experience but hacking, especially frequent hacking, makes it all worthless. And unfortunately Hurtworld is a victim of such. :(

19537320.review:
Hurtworld is a title that looks to compete in a genre that is completely oversaturating the market, especially in regards to Early Access games. Many of its gameplay elements are similar to its more popular predecessors, namely games such as Rust, DayZ, and Ark. However, while Hurtworld does not introduce many new concepts to the genre, it takes these preexisting gameplay elements and polishes them up to a shine not often found in Early Access titles.

Most of the work done in both the closed Alpha and Beta was to create a stable and optimized foundation for new content to be added to when the game reached Early Access; compared to other games, FPS is relatively stable even at higher settings on lower end machines, and because the server handles a significant amount of the game calculations,  are more reliable, albeit more slow. This means far fewer instances of players hacking, and more accurate hitboxes for PvP, though it also means ping will be the determinate factor for how long it takes for that rock you picked up to show up in your inventory.

There seems to be a great deal of planning that went into the overall progression and balance of Hurtworld. Although lacking in content and variety, the existing model and flow is generally more enjoyable. Rather than giving tools durability and punishing the player with the annoyance of repairing and recrafting the same basic item every 50+ uses, many items and tools do not degrade in health and remain in the player's inventory even after death. This means more of the player's time is spent collecting resources, building bases, and interacting with other players, rather than mass-crafting a number of tools to ensure they are able to cut down a few trees by the end of the day.

On the topic of PvP, because the focus of the title is survival from the standpoint of environmental and player interaction rather than from the standpoint of mass collection of raw materials, the infamy system does a relatively fine job of keeping high tier players from picking on low tier new players. Because tools, clothing, and weapons stay in your inventory unless your infamy is above 1, and because infamy is only generated by killing other players, most players refrain from wasting their infamy on kills that are not profitable from an objective standpoint. Instead, high tier players tend to focus their PvP, if they do decide they need to kill, on other individuals that actually pose a threat to them; those with guns, cars, and bases.

The art style is reminscent of TF2, with highly saturated colors, beautifully hand drawn art, and clean, low poly models. This makes the environment rather ironically comfortable to play in, and provides a warm setting to relax in when not in immediate danger, but nicely juxtaposes to the actual risk and threat of death. Similarly, the colors and shapes make distinguishing players and fauna a much easier task on lower resolution monitors, where noisy models and textures create messy scenes over the vast open world of most survival games.

Overall, Hurtworld is a rare gem of polish and potential, and while it lacks in content, the promise of modding opportunities, and beautiful code framework that has been put in place for these new additions, and the general developer transparency, put this game at a relatively good starting place if compared to titles of the same genre. If you already own Rust, Ark, DayZ, etc. and feel burned out on this type of gameplay, I do not recommend this game, as you won't find much new here.

However, if you're relatively new to the genre, or found the poor performance and clunkiness of these other titles did not suite your gameplay requirements, Hurtworld provides oddly satisfying gunplay and a reliable network free from many of the meta issues that plague other games on the market. I would recommend supporting these developers in the hope that the interest in the game spurns their updates to be released timely and regularly, with the same polish as the rest of the title.

40912467.review:
Coming from many hours sunk into Rust, I really tried to like this game. It offers so much opportunity to improve on other games in this genre, but in the end, you are much better off giving it more time to see if it will develop.   As it stands right now, it is not worth your time or money. 

PROS:
+ The graphic style, while a little cartoonish at first, does work.  It looks nice and objects stand out in gameplay.

+ Emphasis on survival.  You really can die of hunger and the elements if you do not take care of yourself.

+ It is satisfying to build up your equipment.  No blueprint BS, just build and buff your stuff.

CONS:
- It is DEAD online.  You need to enjoy working by yourself and getting your hat handed to you by the one or two quasi clans on the few servers that sport more than 3 people online at any time.  This is a major problem that causes the other cons to spiral down even quicker.

- It lacks direction.  The devs have abandoned V1 and now work on V2, which they call Experimental.  Makes you think it is a beta version, right?  Well, it sure is, but it is the only one with anything new, too.  The Devs change course seemingly update to update on the game direction, making major shifts.  This has made the game have a continuous learning curve, and rendered most online guides useless.   More than anything, this game really does not know what it wants to be when it grows up.  It has begun borrowing from other games like Rust, but sometimes without offering any new twist on the ideas.

- It lacks a community.  Remember when I said it was dead?  Most players have left until things settle down.  No one is bothering to write guides, etc. when everything changes in short order.  Long time players are split between one group that wants it to be more and another that tells them to shut up and let the Devs work.  The Devs have apparently said they have made the decision not to try to rebuild the player base at this time and work on the game mechanics instead.  This is a terrible mistake, and might really mean they do not know how to bring them back.  It has meant that the two remaining camps are now just an echo chamber, and it is hard for new ideas to emerge from the community, which to me is one of the major benefits of early access.

- It is buggy.  Expect things that worked yesterday to be broken today.  Expect a lot of hot fixes and server restarts.  Expect long reported problems to remain an issue.  Expect your **** to suddenly disappear from your inventory, your furnace and your storage containers.  Base building, which at first seems such an upgrade to other games, will become a nightmare over time when you try to lay a foundation that will just not ********** snap into the correct position for no known reason.

- And the worse for last, it is tedious.  There is no end game, no real goal during play.  You will farm and grind, build up your equipment, gaining that previously mentioned satisfaction and then... nothing.  The same six mobs will do the same damn thing, run in the same damn patterns and give you the same damn loot regardless of how hard they are to kill.  There is not a great variety to equipment, or different things to do with it.  How you use it really doesn't matter.  Perhaps the worst examples are the landmarks, some of which are radioactive (sound familiar?).  The first time you find one, you will be excited.  Then you will notice the textures are missing; the buildings look very bland.  Still you will race around looking for that sweet loot.  Nope!  Most have nothing more than a rock to crush or a log to chop.  You cannot enter the buildings.  You can climb a few ladders, but this just wastes a few minutes and leads literally no where.

In the end, you will feel like Tom Hanks in Castway.  Alone, bored, day after day the same, nothing to do besides talking to Wilson, except Wilson isn't even a vollyball.  He's just a moldy orange with a weird name.   There are thousands of games on steam for $25 or less that will be far more satisfying.  Vote yourself off the island and buy one of those instead.

Solid (and very fun) little game at this time, Please note however that content is still constantly under construction. 

Positives:
+ Generally smooth performance
+ Decent voip and nameplates only appear when very close 
+ Variety of PVE encounters that can actually be challenging 
+ Excellent base building mechanics
+ Large number of gfx options
+ Huge and varied map
+ FOV slider (why do more games not have this?)
+ Bandit/Karma/Infamy system (needs work however foundation is there)
+ Base raiding is possible but very expensive
+ Dev team listen to and liase with the community.

Negatives:
- Tiering needs looking at
- Resource spawning can take a long time 
- Few weapon options
- Some rubber banding. 
- Possibly a memory leak/gfx glitch, perfomance seems to decrease over time (using Nvidia(maxwell) gpu) 
- Not much in the way of resource variety
- Over reliance on certain resoures
- Food doesn't stack which is more an irritance than a challenge 
- Few bugs like clipping through walls, mobs spawning on players etc.
- Rumors of hacking already surfacing. 
- No Server que system

The overall sucesss of this game will depend on how often the devs fix bugs and add new content.

38816613.review:
Does it have a potential? - yes. Is it good and stable in it's current release? - no. It says I have ~50 h on it. I have actually played much more on the pirated version, before deciding to support the devs. 

Pros:

+ There are two different gamemodes. Vanilla (base game, doesn't get updates often) and V2 (is more similar to Rust). The second one is more up to date, seems to be more balanced and overall seems to run better.
+ There are cars, motorcycles and four-wheelers. Some servers have kits to make it easy for you to get them. Usually you will have to farm pieces to make your vehicle functional. 
+ Game is not as harsh as Rust. If you are not into PvP, on death you will only loose resources that you have in your inventory. You will keep all your equiped gear and weapons if you are not infamous. If you are into PvP, you will notice that there is a unique "infamous" system which I mentioned earlier. If you have it, you are basically marked as a bandit and you will drop random equiped gear after death.  
+ Colorful and good looking graphics.
+ Nice base building system. (Similar to Rust).
+ Different biomes, with different resource nodes and more or less, different aggresive animals. (Only skin changes, not the model.)

Cons:

- Guns are NOT balanced at all. People will bunny-jump near you and shoot you with a shotgun using only one round. (Because when you jump, its accuracy becomes better? What? Yes.) Assault rifles have the same accuracy as bolt action rifles. You just need to get used to it. (Balanced? Nope), same goes for the pistol, but for a lower damage output. Bolt action seems to be in overall, most balanced. 
- Optimization. Oh boy, you will lag a lot. (More frequent in "community servers") This will be especially noticable in close, face to face fights. :) (Most people try to abuse it, they will jump around and with added server/game lag you will most likely be on the other side of the stick). Prepare your nerves and attidude that this is just an unfinished game and shit does happen.  
- Animals, I have been playing this game for two years and they still seem to be some what bugged. It is not as bad as it used to be, but they will try to make your day miserable. (In V2 most animals will run from you, in vanila they will attack you and if you are into PvP, get prepared to be overhelmed.) 
- Raiding. There are no secure doors in hurtworld. Doesn't matter how though your base is, doors only require one C4 to be destroyed. My suggestion: if there is /sethome command in the server, use it and just teleport back to your home when you leave (have an exit on the 3rd floor or something). Do NOT build wooden houses. Please. Unless you aren't planning to keep your precious resources there and just want to rp. (Which I would not recommend).
- Cheaters, exploiters, hackers. you name it. You will encounter them. Wallhacks and aimbots (usually aimbots accure in PvP based servers) are there and people using them are not punished. (additional note, usually russians do it. Damn commies.)
